sent: Elon Musk, an entrepreneur and engineer, founded SpaceX to develop advanced rockets and spacecraft capable of reducing the cost of space travel.
Sundar Pichai, an Indian-American business executive, became the CEO of Google in 2015, leading the company’s growth in artificial intelligence and cloud computing.
Bill Gates co-founded Microsoft with Paul Allen in 1975, laying the groundwork for the personal computer revolution.
Barack Obama, the 44th President of the United States, was born in Honolulu, Hawaii, in 1961.
Taylor Swift wrote and recorded the song Love Story in 2008, inspired by Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet.
Martin Luther King Jr., a Baptist minister and civil rights leader, served as the first president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference during the 1950s.
Stanford University, a private research university established in 1885, is located in Stanford, California.
The Eiffel Tower, a wrought-iron lattice structure completed in 1889, stands in Paris as one of the most recognizable landmarks in the world.
Albert Einstein, a theoretical physicist, received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect.
Marie Curie, a pioneer in radioactivity research, won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1911 for her discovery of radium and polonium.
Nelson Mandela, a South African anti-apartheid activist, served as the leader of the African National Congress and became the country’s first black president in 1994.
Mahatma Gandhi led the Indian National Congress in India’s struggle for independence through nonviolent civil disobedience during the early 20th century.
Nintendo developed The Legend of Zelda, an action-adventure game first released in 1986 that became one of the company’s most successful franchises.
Rockstar Games created Grand Theft Auto, a series known for its open-world design and controversial themes since its debut in 1997.
Valve developed Half-Life, a first-person shooter released in 1998 that revolutionized storytelling in video games.
